1. Four. There would be one contact in Address Book and three in ClaimCenter. Every contact, whether it is linked or not, is a unique and separate object.

2. It is common to have a contact that exists only in ClaimCenter. This is true for contacts that are relevant to only one claim (such as a witness). It is uncommon to have a contact exist only in Address Book. The primary purpose for creating a contact in Address Book is to have it associated to multiple claims, and if it is associated to even one claim, then the contact will also exist in ClaimCenter.

3. A linked ClaimCenter contact object has a logical matching object in Address Book. A ClaimCenter contact object that is in sync is linked to an Address Book contact and all of its field values are identical to the Address Book version.

4. A contact role identifies the relationship that the contact has with the claim (such as insured, witness, doctor, and so on). The contact role owner identifies if the contact has that role for the entire claim or for just the policy, a given exposure, or a given incident.
5. You can tell that a contact is linked and/or in sync by selecting the contact from the Parties Involved - Contacts screen. A label on the Basic card identifies the contact's state.

6. Assuming that the contact is a "multi-use" contact which has linked instances in both ClaimCenter and Address Book, you could view the contact in Address Book (either by finding the contact from a Parties Involved - Contacts screen and clicking the "View in Address Book" button or by searching for it via the Address Book tab), and then view the Claims card, which lists all claims the contact is linked to.

2. An activity pattern is a template used to create activities.

c) The activity is overdue. (It is open past its due date.)

Both lists list activities.
Both lists have filtering criteria to modify which activities appear.
Both lists have an analogous calendar which lists the activities in calendar format.
Possible answers (differences):
Desktop Activities lists activities assigned to you (regardless of the claim involved). Claim Workplan lists activities associated to a claim (whether they're assigned to you or not).
5. An activity can be completed or skipped. A completed activity's work has been done. A skipped activity's work has not been done but is no longer relevant and does not need to be done.

1. A document "known to exist" is not stored in the document management system (and therefore cannot be viewed or edited). An electronic document is stored in the document management system (and therefore can be viewed and possibly edited).
2. A document's MIME type identifies what kind of document the document is, which is used by the user's machine to determine the application to use when viewing the document.

- Creating a new document from a template

Typically, a user does not have to edit a document to provide names, addresses, claim numbers, dates, and any other information which is already stored by ClaimCenter. This information can automatically be inserted into the document.

4. Activities, documents, and notes

c) No. You can't tell. (The number of payment transactions is not tied to the number of payees.)

A user who has broader responsibility than another user can be given additional roles so that they are able to accomplish these responsibilities.

2. Own access, view access, edit access.

3. The security profile generates a list of users based on the criteria. The users who actually meet the criteria vary from claim to claim. For example, if a profile says only the claim owner and members of his group can view and edit the claim, then two claims will have different access control lists if they are owned by users in different groups.

4. Multiple security profiles are useful when you have multiple types of claims where each type needs its own approach to generating access control lists. For example, the strategy needed for a regular claim (an unsecured claim) is different than that needed for an employee claim. Each approach typically translates to its own security profile.
5. A security zone is used to provide similar access to a given claim to people in different groups.

6. The fourth criteria pertains to claim user roles. For example, a profile could specify that anyone with the role of legal on the claim (or anyone in the same group or security zone as the user) can access the claim.

qaPairs.question: 1. Whether or not the user can be authenticated, what are the user's roles (permissions), and what is the user's startup page.
2. Possible answers:
qaPairs.answer:
A given tab might be visible or not visible.
A given menu link might be visible or not visible.
A given menu action may have fewer or more menu items within it.

qaPairs.question: 3. Possible answers:
qaPairs.answer:
The screen area is always visible, whereas the workspace frame appears only if something is rendered within it.
The screen area contains the majority of the business data, whereas the workspace frame contains data that is navigationally distinct from the screen area.
If the screen area contains multiple sets of information, each is accessed via a "subtab" link and all subtab links are always visible, whereas if the workspace frame contains multiple sets of information, each is accessed via a tab and that tab may or may not always be visible depending on what is displayed in the screen area.

qaPairs.question: 4. Four (or five). An adjuster can access four tabs (Desktop, Claim, Address Book, Search), and each tab has its own side bar. (If an adjuster is designated as the backup user for another user on vacation, then the Vacation tab becomes active and a fifth side bar can be viewed.

5. In ClaimCenter, the Internet Explorer Back button is not supported. This is due to limitations with Internet Explorer and the fact that ClaimCenter is a series of dynamic HTML pages (as opposed to static HTML pages). In most cases, to view a screen previously viewed, you must re-navigate to it. Fortunately, there are a large number of shortcuts (such as the list of recently viewed claims in the Claim tab menu). Consequently, viewing a previously viewed screen is typically only a few clicks away.
6. Navigations navigate to the screen level.
7. The Unsaved Work menu is available only when there is unsaved work. If a user attempts to log off ClaimCenter and there is unsaved work, a dialog box alerts them to this fact.
qaPairs.answer: Answers

qaPairs.question: 1.	a) Incident

c) Activity

e) Policy (see Note)
f) Contact

qaPairs.question: 2. Not necessarily. It is not unusual for a claim to have exposures and/or activities assigned to someone other than the claim owner, and it is not unusual for other users to have user claim roles on the claim (such as legal or subrogation specialist). All the ClaimCenter users associated to the claim are listed on the Parties Involves --> Users list.
qaPairs.answer:
There is also only one group assigned to the claim, but group-to-claim is one-to-many, as a group presumably owns many claims. But couldn’t you say the same for Policy? There is only a single group object, and it can have many claims associated with it - in fact, there is an array key called Group.OpenClaims. There are, however, as many Policy objects as there are claims, because we make a clone of the PAS exported policy. The now deprecated array key Policy.Claims was a virtual field to provide a way to locate all the claims that were originally derived from the Policy.

qaPairs.question: 1. Four. There would be one contact in Address Book and three in ClaimCenter. Every contact, whether it is linked or not, is a unique and separate object.

2. It is common to have a contact that exists only in ClaimCenter. This is true for contacts that are relevant to only one claim (such as a witness). It is uncommon to have a contact exist only in Address Book. The primary purpose for creating a contact in Address Book is to have it associated to multiple claims, and if it is associated to even one claim, then the contact will also exist in ClaimCenter.

3. A linked ClaimCenter contact object has a logical matching object in Address Book. A ClaimCenter contact object that is in sync is linked to an Address Book contact and all of its field values are identical to the Address Book version.

4. A contact role identifies the relationship that the contact has with the claim (such as insured, witness, doctor, and so on). The contact role owner identifies if the contact has that role for the entire claim or for just the policy, a given exposure, or a given incident.
5. You can tell that a contact is linked and/or in sync by selecting the contact from the Parties Involved - Contacts screen. A label on the Basic card identifies the contact's state.

6. Assuming that the contact is a "multi-use" contact which has linked instances in both ClaimCenter and Address Book, you could view the contact in Address Book (either by finding the contact from a Parties Involved - Contacts screen and clicking the "View in Address Book" button or by searching for it via the Address Book tab), and then view the Claims card, which lists all claims the contact is linked to.
qaPairs.answer: Answers

qaPairs.question: 1. ClaimCenter determines the permissions for a given user when that user logs in.
2. A role can have any number of permissions, from zero (which would serve no business purpose but is theoretically possibly) to many.

3. A user can theoretically have any number of roles from zero to many. A user must have at least one role in order to be able to do something in ClaimCenter. A user who has broader responsibility than another user can be given additional roles so that they are able to accomplish these responsibilities.

4. You could view the create matter permission in the security dictionary to see which roles the permission has been added to. Note that this only works for the base product, because the security dictionary will not update based on any changes that a project team or security administrator makes to the roles.
qaPairs.answer: Answers

qaPairs.question: 1. The user probably lacks the system permission to view and/or edit claims. In order to view or edit a claim, the user must have the system permission and appear on the ACL.
2. Own access, view access, edit access.

3. The security profile generates a list of users based on the criteria. The users who actually meet the criteria vary from claim to claim. For example, if a profile says only the claim owner and members of his group can view and edit the claim, then two claims will have different access control lists if they are owned by users in different groups.

4. Multiple security profiles are useful when you have multiple types of claims where each type needs its own approach to generating access control lists. For example, the strategy needed for a regular claim (an unsecured claim) is different than that needed for an employee claim. Each approach typically translates to its own security profile.
5. A security zone is used to provide similar access to a given claim to people in different groups.

6. The fourth criteria pertains to claim user roles. For example, a profile could specify that anyone with the role of legal on the claim (or anyone in the same group or security zone as the user) can access the claim.
qaPairs.answer: Answers

An internal typelist cannot be extended. An extendable typelist can be extended.
The typecode must be unique within the typelist and must have 50 characters or fewer. (It also must contain no characters other than alphanumerics, underscores, periods, commas, hyphens, and colons.
The priority value of each typecode determines the sort order. (When priority values are the same, the values are sorted alphabetically by Name.)

A varchar <column> tag creates a field that can have any string value (less than or equal to the given size). A <typekey> tag creates a field that can be set only to the values in the corresponding typelist.
The first field is limited to all the values in the typelist. The second field is limited to some named subset of values in the typelist.

1. Every rule set is tied to an entity, known as the root entity. This determines which class of objects the rule set is tied to. It also determines the object available to the rules in the rule set when the rule set is triggered.
2. A rule set is triggered when a given event occurs to any instance of the root entity. The actual event varies from rule set to rule set.
3. The rule action is executed and the child rules (if any) are executed.

4. In an "execute all" rule set, all rules are executed. For example, validation rule sets are execute all. All validation conditions are checked, regardless of how many are true. In an "exit after first action" rule set, you do not typically execute all rules. When the first true condition is found, the action associated with that condition is taken and the rule set is exited. For example, assignment rule sets are exit after first action. Once an assignment is made, the rule set exits so that later code doesn't reassign the object.
5. The rule is not executed by the rules engine, which is useful in development for turning rules "on" and "off".
6. Other than saving the changes to a rule, you do not need to do anything to deploy the rule. If Studio is connected to the application server, the changes are immediately available.

An internal typelist cannot be extended. An extendable typelist can be extended.
The typecode must be unique within the typelist and must have 50 characters or fewer. (It also must contain no characters other than alphanumerics, underscores, periods, commas, hyphens, and colons.
The priority value of each typecode determines the sort order. (When priority values are the same, the values are sorted alphabetically by Name.)
A varchar <column> tag creates a field that can have any string value (less than or equal to the given size). A <typekey> tag creates a field that can be set only to the values in the corresponding typelist.
The first field is limited to all the values in the typelist. The second field is limited to some named subset of values in the typelist.

qaPairs.question: 1. Every rule set is tied to an entity, known as the root entity. This determines which class of objects the rule set is tied to. It also determines the object available to the rules in the rule set when the rule set is triggered.
2. A rule set is triggered when a given event occurs to any instance of the root entity. The actual event varies from rule set to rule set.
3. The rule action is executed and the child rules (if any) are executed.

4. In an "execute all" rule set, all rules are executed. For example, validation rule sets are execute all. All validation conditions are checked, regardless of how many are true. In an "exit after first action" rule set, you do not typically execute all rules. When the first true condition is found, the action associated with that condition is taken and the rule set is exited. For example, assignment rule sets are exit after first action. Once an assignment is made, the rule set exits so that later code doesn't reassign the object.
5. The rule is not executed by the rules engine, which is useful in development for turning rules "on" and "off".
6. Other than saving the changes to a rule, you do not need to do anything to deploy the rule. If Studio is connected to the application server, the changes are immediately available.
qaPairs.answer: Answers

content.text: Document 28 :
What did u do in your last project?
In the last project I have been working on all the three layers of guidewire claim center,Policy center and Billing center.

In data model we created new entities, we enhanced or extended existing entities using etx files, created new subtypes and entities using eti files , but in the project actually  we do not create eti files and etx files but we give the script to them (database team)..we give the entity tags and the field sub tags like column, array key ,foreign key ,type key tags and along with the attribute value we provide to data model team and the data model team will build the eti and etx files required .. my job is limited to providing the script for data model teams for my extensions and for my new entities required.

In business layer I worked extensively on business rules particularly assignment rules, workplan rules for creating activities required and I worked on segmentation rules and also other business logic which is commonly used or written in some utility classes which are called from different places including rules ..and my work is mostly involved on UI.

In UI I have created new exposure screens , new incident screens  because the client needed some new coverage’s for professional liability , so we have created new exposure and new incident screens and we have totally refactored (changed )the negotiation screens ,evaluation screens ,legal matter screens and we did work on lot of changes to the loss details screen. What we have done is instead of creating  two column structure for all the pages in UI which is default in OOTB application we changed that into single column structure.. that’s what the user wanted …so we created the pages using a single column… the reason for it is sometimes the width is too much because of which the user has to drag the navigational box.. so they wanted to create a single column which we did. we did modify almost all UI pages. we required an extensive modification on the pages.

I did create the logic in the Gosu classes which are called by the pcf files..  This logic is written is some utility functions and in addition to this I have written couple of enhancements to incidents , enhancements to exposure and some enhancements to claim . so those enhancements are called by my application which I did. And I am also involved in peer code review , In my team I review the code of my colleagues and they review my code.. we call it a peer code review and we do it every two weeks and once peer code review is done the peer code reviews review comments will be implemented on the following day.. normally on Fridays.. final code review is done by team lead
